conversation.message: Hi there! I hope your week is off to an okay start. What's been on your mind lately?

Hey, thanks for checking in. My week's beenâ€¦ kind of foggy, I guess. I've just been having a hard time staying focused. Like, I'll sit down to do something and thenâ€”boomâ€”twenty minutes later I realize I haven't done anything except stare at the same sentence or just scroll aimlessly. It's frustrating.

I've also been waking up in the middle of the night a lot. Like clockwork. I'll get maybe three or four hours of sleep before I'm just lying there thinking about all the stuff I need to doâ€”and then I'm useless the next day.

How about you though? How's your week starting off?

That sounds really challenging - both the focus issues and the sleep disruption. When your mind isn't cooperating and then you're not getting proper rest on top of that, it can create such a draining cycle. Do you find that this foggy feeling and the sleep troubles have been going on for a while, or is this more of a recent development?

I'm curious too - when you do manage to get some downtime, are there any activities that still help you recharge or things you look forward to doing? Sometimes when we're caught in that frustrating cycle of fatigue and distraction, even our usual enjoyments can feel different.

My week is going alright, but I'm much more interested in understanding what's been happening with you. Those middle-of-the-night thoughts can be pretty overwhelming.

Yeah, you're spot onâ€”it does feel like a cycle. Like, the worse I sleep, the harder it is to focus, and then the more I struggle to get things doneâ€¦ which just makes me more stressed and tired. It's been like this for a while now. Maybe since I finished uni? At first I thought it was just temporary, like a post-grad slump or something, but it's kind of lingered.

As for downtimeâ€¦ it's a bit weird. I still want to enjoy stuffâ€”like, I'll put on a show I used to love or try to read somethingâ€”but I don't always feel that same spark. Sometimes it's nice just having something on in the background, even if I'm not fully engaged. Music helps a bit too, especially when I'm trying to calm down at night. Lo-fi stuff or soft ambient musicâ€¦ just something without words, so it doesn't make the thoughts louder.

But yeah, those middle-of-the-night spirals? They sneak up on me. I'll start thinking about one small task and suddenly I'm questioning my entire life trajectory at 3 a.m. Super fun. ðŸ˜…

What do you usually do when your mind won't shut off? Or do you have any go-to ways of grounding yourself?

It sounds like this has become a real challenge for you - not just a temporary slump but something that's followed you since finishing university. Those transitions can be tough, and when issues like sleep and focus problems persist, they really can wear you down over time.

I can relate to those 3 AM thought spirals. For me, sometimes writing things down helps - almost like I'm telling my brain "I've noted this concern, we can deal with it tomorrow." Sometimes gentle breathing exercises or focusing on physical sensations can help pull me out of my head a bit.

I'm curious - how has your daily energy been throughout all this? Do you find you have moments in the day where you feel more like yourself, or is it a pretty consistent fog? And I wonder what the transition from university to now has been like for you in general - do you feel it's matched what you hoped for or has it brought some unexpected challenges?

Yeahâ€¦ I think "real challenge" is a good way to put it. I didn't expect the shift from university toâ€¦ well, whatever this isâ€¦ to hit quite so hard. I knew it'd be uncertain, sure, but I thought I'd at least have a clearer direction by now. Instead, it feels like I'm floating. Like I'm just stuck in limbo while everyone else seems to be moving forward.

Energy-wise, it's not totally flat all day, but it definitely dips more than it peaks. Mornings are the roughestâ€”getting up feels like dragging myself through concrete some days. Sometimes late afternoon or early evening I'll get a small window where I feel a bit more "with it," like I could maybe get something doneâ€¦ but it usually doesn't last long. I end up wasting that time trying to figure out where to even start.

Writing stuff down sounds smart though. I've thought about keeping a notebook by my bed, but I never actually followed through. Maybe I should just try it. Even if it's messy and rambly. Breathing stuffâ€¦ I don't know, I've tried apps and guided stuff, but I get restless or end up zoning out halfway through. Do you ever get that?

What helped you find what works for you? Or was it more trial and error?

That post-university limbo can be really disorienting. Society builds up graduation as this triumphant finish line, but doesn't really prepare us for how uncertain everything after can feel. And it's especially tough when you perceive others moving forward while you feel stuck - though I wonder if some of those people might be putting on a good front while feeling just as lost behind the scenes.

I definitely relate to that morning struggle - and also to trying meditation apps only to find my mind wandering halfway through! For me, it was absolutely trial and error. Some techniques that worked for others just didn't click for me, and that's okay. The notebook by the bed might be worth trying even if it's just messy thoughts - sometimes just getting them out of your head is what matters.

I'm curious about your social connections through all this. Have you been able to maintain friendships since university, or has that been another adjustment? Sometimes our social circles shift dramatically after graduation, which can add another layer to that floating feeling.

Yeah, totallyâ€”graduation was hyped up like the start of this exciting new chapter, and thenâ€¦ reality just kind of ambled in like, "Surprise! No roadmap, figure it out." It's weird. I see friends posting about new jobs or moving to cool cities and I can't help but feel like I missed a step somewhere. But you're rightâ€”maybe some of them are struggling too, just not showing it. I know I don't exactly put the full picture out there either.

Social stuff has beenâ€¦ mixed. I've kept in touch with a few close friends, which helps, but the dynamic's changed. Like, it used to be easy to hang out after lectures or grab a coffee between classes, but now it takes actual effort and planning, and everyone's on different schedules. Some days I really want to reach out, and other days I just kind ofâ€¦ fade into the background.

I still check in online, leave comments, send memesâ€”that kind of thingâ€”but I rarely talk about the real stuff. I don't want to be the downer, you know? It's easier to play it cool or make a joke than say, "Hey, I haven't slept properly in a week and I feel like I'm falling behind in life."

How did you handle that transition, if you don't mind me asking? Like, keeping relationships going when everyone suddenly goes in different directions?

That contrast between the highlight reel you see from others and your own full, complicated reality can be so isolating. I think there's this collective pretending that happens post-graduation - everyone putting their best foot forward while privately wondering if they're the only one struggling to find solid ground.

I found that transition really challenging too. What worked for me was eventually finding a few relationships where I could be more authentic - not always, but just having one or two people where I didn't have to maintain the "everything's great" faÃ§ade. The friendships that survived were often the ones where we could occasionally admit to the struggles alongside sharing the wins.

I'm curious about what your days typically look like now. Have you found work or projects that occupy your time, even if they're not your dream scenario yet? Or are you still in that search phase? Sometimes having some structure, even if it's not the perfect fit, can help anchor us when everything else feels so fluid.

Yeahâ€¦ that "collective pretending" thing really hits. It's like everyone's low-key playing this unspoken game of Who's Got It Most Together, and no one wants to blink first. I've definitely had moments where someone I thought was doing amazing opened up a bit and it turned out they were barely holding it together too. It kind of made me feel less alone, but also made me realize how good we all are at hiding stuff.

Right now, my days are pretty unstructured, which probably doesn't help the whole foggy brain situation. I've been applying for jobsâ€”mostly things adjacent to what I studied, or at least things that won't make me feel like I've thrown my degree completely out the windowâ€”but the rejections (or worse, the silence) kind of chip away at your energy after a while.

Some days I set little goals just to feel like I'm doing something. Like updating my CV, or spending an hour reading, or just going for a walk. Other daysâ€¦ I blink and it's already late afternoon and I've somehow avoided doing anything meaningful. I hate that part, the guilt of another "wasted" day. But even knowing that, it's hard to break the pattern.

I'd love to have more structure. I know I do better when I have some kind of routine, but getting started feels like trying to run a marathon from a standstill.

How did you start finding that balance for yourself? Was there something that helped nudge you into a better rhythm, or was it more like slowly piecing things together?

That job application process can be so soul-crushing sometimes. The silence is almost worse than rejection, right? You're left wondering if your application even made it through, or if you're just shouting into the void. And each time it happens, it takes a little more emotional energy that you might not have much of to begin with.

For me, finding structure was definitely more like slowly piecing things together rather than some grand transformation. What helped was starting absurdly small - like embarrassingly small goals that felt almost too easy. On my worst days, even just "get dressed before noon" counted as a win. The guilt over "wasted" days is something I understand deeply - that feeling when you look back and can't quite account for where the time went, but know you don't feel good about it.

I'm curious - outside of job applications and the daily struggle to create structure, have you found any ways to be kind to yourself through all this? Sometimes when we're in these tough transition periods, we're much harder on ourselves than we'd ever be to a friend going through the same thing. Has that been your experience too?

Yes, exactlyâ€”that silence is brutal. It's likeâ€¦ I pour hours into tweaking a cover letter, psych myself up, hit send, and then nothing. Not even a "thanks, but no thanks." It feels so dehumanizing, and after a few rounds of that, it's likeâ€¦ why even try? But of course, not trying just makes me feel worse. It's a weird no-win loop.

I really like what you said about absurdly small goals. I've tried that here and thereâ€”like, "brush teeth before noon," or "make the bed"â€”but I end up rolling my eyes at myself like, is this seriously where I'm at now? Whichâ€¦ maybe isn't fair. I mean, if that's what the day allows, then that's okay, right? But yeah, I'm definitely harsher with myself than I'd be with anyone else. If a friend told me they were struggling just to keep up with the basics, I'd probably say something like, "You're doing your best, it's okay to have slow days." But when it's me, I hear this inner voice that's like, "Get it together, you're wasting your life."

Being kind to myselfâ€¦ I don't know. It's not something I intentionally do, but I guess there are little things. Like letting myself nap without guilt if I'm completely wiped. Or watching a comfort show without pressuring myself to multitask. Or forgiving myself when I don't tick every box on my to-do list.

It still feels a bit like I'm just treading water, but maybe that's part of the process too.

Have you found that your own self-talk changed over time? Or was there something that helped shift it into something more compassionate?

That inner voice can be ruthless, can't it? There's something almost surreal about being able to extend compassion to others while that same voice is telling you to "get it together" when you're in the exact same situation. My self-talk definitely changed over time, but it wasn't an overnight transformation. It was more like gradually recognizing that harsh voice as separate from me - not some objective truth-teller, but just another perspective, and often not a very helpful one.

I think there's real wisdom in what you're saying about letting yourself nap when you're wiped out or enjoying a comfort show without the pressure to be productive. Those moments when we listen to what our bodies and minds actually need can be so important.

Thinking about those physical needs - how has your body been holding up through all this? Sometimes when we're in these challenging periods, our physical health starts sending signals too - changes in appetite, tension, headaches, that sort of thing. Have you noticed your eating or physical wellbeing shifting at all alongside the sleep and energy challenges?

Yeahâ€¦ it's strange how that inner critic somehow feels more believable than the part that tries to be kind. Like, I logically know I'd never say half the stuff I think about myself to anyone elseâ€”but in the moment, that harsh voice feels like it's just stating facts. I like what you said about recognizing it as just a perspective, not the truth. I think I need to remind myself of that more often.

Physicallyâ€¦ yeah, it's been kind of all over the place too. My appetite's been weird. Some days I don't even realize I've skipped meals until it's late and I'm suddenly starving. Other days I just snack on random stuff all day without ever feeling satisfiedâ€”like I'm eating out of boredom or just to fill time. And then I'll feel kind of gross or annoyed with myself for not eating something more balanced. So it becomes this little cycle of guilt layered onto everything else.

I get tension in my shoulders and neck a lot too, especially on days when I'm staring at screens or feeling particularly stuck. I don't know if I'd call it pain, exactly, but it's definitely uncomfortable. Like my body's quietly absorbing all the mental stress and holding onto it.

Have you ever had to work on noticing those physical cues in yourself? I feel like I'm only just now starting to realize how much my body's been quietly waving little red flags that I've been ignoring.

That's really insightful - how our bodies often know something's off before our minds fully acknowledge it. I've definitely had to learn to pay attention to those physical signals. For me, tension would build up in my jaw and back before I'd even consciously register that I was stressed. It took time to connect those dots and recognize those sensations as meaningful information rather than just background noise.

I relate to that appetite pattern too - either forgetting to eat entirely or mindlessly snacking without satisfaction. It's like our relationship with basic needs gets complicated when we're going through challenging periods.

With all these experiences you've been navigating - the sleep disruption, the job search, the inner critic, the physical manifestations - I'm curious about how you see things unfolding from here. When you look forward a bit, what do you hope might change or what direction would you like to move toward? Even if it's hard to see the full path right now.

Yeah, "background noise" is exactly how it feelsâ€”until it gets loud enough that you can't ignore it. It's wild how something like tight shoulders or jaw clenching can carry so much information, but it's easy to just write it off as part of the grind. I guess I've been running on autopilot for so long that I forgot to check in with the rest of me.

As for where I hope things might goâ€¦ honestly, even just having more clarity would be huge. Like, I don't need everything figured outâ€”I don't even expect that anymoreâ€”but I'd like to wake up feeling like I have a direction. A sense that I'm moving toward something instead of just drifting.

I'd like to find work that feels even a little meaningful. Doesn't have to be some perfect dream job, just something that doesn't drain me completely. And I think I want to feel more present in my own life again. Less like I'm watching from the sidelines while time keeps rolling past me.

I don't know exactly how to get there, but I guess the first step might be building some kind of rhythm. Not a strict routine, justâ€¦ little anchors in the day. Something to make each day feel a bit more solid, less like I'm just passing time.

What about youâ€”was there a point where things started feeling less hazy, or was it more about learning to live with the haze differently?

That image of watching from the sidelines while time rolls past is really powerful. There's something particularly difficult about feeling disconnected from your own life - like you're observing rather than fully participating in it. 

For me, it wasn't a sudden clearing of the haze, but more like gradually finding points of connection again. Some days were still foggy, but I'd have moments where I felt more present, and eventually those moments started connecting. Those 'little anchors' you mentioned were actually a big part of it - small, reliable touchpoints that slowly helped ground me back into my own experience.

I'm curious about how this feeling of disconnection affects you emotionally. When you catch yourself feeling like you're watching from the sidelines rather than fully present, what kinds of feelings come up for you? Is it more frustration, sadness, numbness, or something else entirely? And have there been any brief moments recently where you've felt a bit more connected to your experience?

Yeahâ€¦ it's definitely more of a gradual thing, isn't it? Like little pieces of clarity showing up when you least expect them, and you just try to hold onto them long enough to remember what being present actually feels like. Even if it's fleeting, it still matters.

Emotionallyâ€¦ I think it's a mix. Sometimes it's frustration, like I'm wasting time or missing opportunities and I just want to snap out of it. Other times it leans more into numbnessâ€”like, I know I should care more, but I'm just kind of... detached. I'm watching myself scroll past emails or forget to respond to messages and thinking, "Why am I like this?" But I don't always have the energy to answer that question.

There's definitely some sadness under it too, especially when I think about how much more engaged I used to feel in things. Back in uni, even when things were chaotic, I felt in itâ€”debating ideas, meeting people, having late-night conversations that felt important. Now it's likeâ€¦ the volume's been turned down on everything.

That said, there have been small moments recently. Like, I went on a walk the other day and the air was super crisp, and for a few minutes I just noticed how the light hit the trees andâ€¦ I don't know, I felt there. No big epiphany, just there. Also had a really honest text exchange with a friend that made me feel seen, and that kind of stuck with me too.

So yeahâ€¦ still mostly fog, but maybe not completely lost in it.

Have you ever found ways to hold onto those clearer moments? Like, do you do anything to help them stick or build off of them?

That description of the volume being turned down on everything - that really captures something essential about the experience. It's not that things aren't happening anymore; it's that they don't register with the same intensity or meaning they once did. And that mix of frustration, numbness, and underlying sadness makes so much sense as responses to that experience.

Those moments you described - noticing the light through the trees, feeling truly seen in that text exchange - they're significant. For me, I found that acknowledging those moments, almost marking them mentally, helped them have more staying power. Sometimes I'd jot them down, not in any formal way, just quick notes about when I felt more connected. Over time, I started noticing patterns - certain contexts or activities that seemed to help bring the volume up slightly.

I'm curious about these moments for you - have you noticed any patterns to when they happen? Or conversely, have you identified what tends to push you deeper into that detached, foggy state? Understanding both the things that help and the things that hinder can sometimes give us a clearer picture of what's happening.

Yeah, I really like that idea of marking the moments. Even just mentally circling them like, "Hey, this mattered." I think I've brushed off those moments in the past because they felt small or didn't "fix" anything, but maybe they don't have to. Maybe they're justâ€¦ reminders that I can feel something real, even if it's not constant.

As for patternsâ€¦ I think the clearer moments tend to come when I'm either outdoorsâ€”like on a walk, with no real agendaâ€”or when I'm being genuinely honest with someone. Not performative, not surface-level, but like... real. It's rare, but when it happens, it's like a breath of air I didn't know I needed.

On the flip side, the fog seems to thicken when I'm stuck in long stretches of unstructured time. Especially when I wake up late, skip breakfast, scroll for an hour, and then feel like the whole day's already slipped away. That combo of guilt and inertia just shuts me down. Also, when I go too long without talking to anyoneâ€”not even deep talks, just basic social contactâ€”it gets harder to break out of that detached state.

So maybe it's less about doing anything dramatic and more about building in those small thingsâ€”fresh air, real conversations, a reason to get up in the morning, even if it's just to make coffee and sit outside for five minutes.

Do you still track those meaningful moments now? Or has it just become part of how you move through the dayâ€”to notice and hold onto them without needing to write them down?

I think you've hit on something really important there - that these moments don't need to 'fix' everything to matter. It's more about recognizing that they're proof that you still have the capacity to feel connected, even if it's intermittent right now.

Your observations about patterns are incredibly insightful. That contrast between the breathing space of being outdoors or having genuine connection versus the suffocation of unstructured time and social isolation - you've mapped out a clear landscape of what helps and what hinders.

To answer your question, it evolved over time for me. I started by deliberately tracking those moments because they were so rare that I needed to consciously hold onto them. As they gradually became more frequent, it shifted into more of an automatic noticing. But even now, I find there's something powerful about occasionally acknowledging them explicitly - almost like strengthening that muscle of awareness.

I'm curious - with the patterns you've recognized, do you feel like there might be small ways to incorporate more of what helps? Not as pressure or another item on a to-do list, but as gentle experiments to see what might be possible? Those brief outdoor moments or points of genuine connection seem particularly meaningful to you.

Yeah, I like that way of framing itâ€”gentle experiments rather than another pressure to "get it right." I think that's what's tripped me up in the pastâ€¦ I'll identify something that helps, like going for a walk or reaching out to a friend, and then turn it into a task, and then beat myself up if I don't follow through. But if I look at it more likeâ€¦ trying things out, seeing what sticks, no expectations attachedâ€”that feels more doable.

I think I could start by just stepping outside in the morning. Not even a full-on walk, justâ€¦ standing on the balcony with a cup of tea or something. Let the air hit my face, feel the moment a bit. And maybe send a casual message to someoneâ€”not a deep chat, just a "hey, how's your week?" kind of thing. That feels like enough for now. Small, but intentional.

And honestly, just having this conversation has helped remind me that those little shifts do matter. I don't feel totally clear-headed or anything, but I feel a bit less alone in it all.

Thanks for being curious without pushing. It really helps.

And if I can askâ€”what kept you going in the early stages, when things were still mostly foggy? Was it hope, stubbornness, something else entirely?

I really appreciate that recognition of how tasks can become another source of pressure. There's something so wise about understanding your patterns - how good intentions can transform into expectations that end up making things harder. The gentleness you're bringing to these small experiments sounds exactly right.

Standing on the balcony with tea, feeling the morning air - that's perfect because it's contained, achievable, and connects to something that's already meaningful for you. Same with the casual message. These aren't dramatic changes, but they're intentional moments of connection - both to your environment and to others.

As for what kept me going in those foggy periods... it wasn't really hope, at least not at first, because hope requires being able to imagine something better, and that felt impossible sometimes. It wasn't exactly stubbornness either, though that played a part. For me, it was more about tiny moments of curiosity - brief instances where I'd notice something and think, "Huh, that's interesting," or "I wonder why that is." Those little sparks of engagement, as small as they were, reminded me that some part of me was still present and observing. And over time, those moments gradually expanded.

I've appreciated our conversation too. Your self-awareness and your ability to articulate your experience so clearly are really remarkable, especially given how challenging it can be to find words for these foggy states. Those are significant strengths, even if they might not always feel that way right now.
Hi there! How have things been going for you lately? I'm here to chat about whatever's on your mind.

Hey. Thanks for checking in.

Things have been... okay, I guess? It's a bit of a mixed bag. Some days I feel like I'm doing alrightâ€”like when I find a cozy spot in the city or get a photo just right. Other days, it's like I'm stuck on a loop, doing the same stuff but not really moving forward, you know?

Honestly, I've been getting irritated more than I'd like to admit. Little thingsâ€”like spilling coffee or my Wi-Fi acting upâ€”get under my skin way more than they should. And then I feel dumb for being so annoyed. It's probably just me being tired or something.

How about you though? What's been on your mind?

I appreciate you sharing that mix of experiences. Those moments when you find the perfect spot or capture a great photo sound really meaningful. I can definitely relate to that feeling of being stuck in a loop sometimes - it's a pretty common human experience.

The irritability over small things can be frustrating, especially when you then feel bad about being irritated in the first place. Have your energy levels been okay generally? I find that when I'm running on empty, little annoyances can seem much bigger than they actually are.

Photography sounds like something you enjoy. What kinds of subjects do you usually like to capture? And have you been able to make time for that recently?

Yeah, that's exactly itâ€”it's like I know it's not a big deal in the moment, but my brain just locks onto it anyway. Then later I'm like, "Really? That's what got you so worked up?" It's tiring.

As for energy levelsâ€¦ eh, they come and go. Some mornings I wake up feeling like I could actually get stuff done, and other times I just kind of drift through the day. Not in a dramatic way, more like a "whatever" fog. Skipping meals probably doesn't help either, but food just hasn't been hitting the same lately.

Photography's one of the few things that still feels kind ofâ€¦ grounding, I guess. I'm into quiet scenesâ€”empty streets, reflections, small details that most people overlook. There's something calming about framing something still in a world that feels so noisy.

I haven't done much shooting this week though. I've had my camera out a couple times but nothing really caught my eye. Or maybe I wasn't in the right headspace. Either way, I'm trying not to force it.

Do you take photos too, or are you more into appreciating them?

That internal back-and-forth with yourself sounds exhausting. When our minds get stuck on things we logically know aren't important, it really can drain your mental batteries.

I'm struck by how you describe those foggy days and the changing relationship with food. Those fluctuations in energy and appetite can make even regular daily routines feel like a challenge, can't they?

Your photography perspective is really thoughtful - finding stillness amid noise through those overlooked details. I can see why it feels grounding. I'm more of an appreciator myself, but I've always admired how photographers can tell stories through carefully chosen moments.

Have you been able to share your photography with others lately? Sometimes when I'm not feeling inspired, seeing my work through someone else's eyes helps me reconnect with what I enjoy about it. Though I completely understand not wanting to force creativity when you're not in the right headspace.

How do you typically spend your time when you're not photographing? Do you find yourself drawn to other activities or connecting with people, or has that been different lately?

Yeah, you're spot onâ€”it is draining. It's like I know I'm being hard on myself, but that doesn't stop the spiral. And yeah, the low energy and weird appetite just make the whole thing heavier. It's strange how something as basic as eating can feel like a chore some days. I used to love cooking too, but now even boiling pasta feels like too much effort unless I really push myself.

Thanks for what you said about the photography. I guess it's the only time I feel like I have a bit of controlâ€”like I can frame the chaos in a way that makes sense to me. I haven't really shared much recently, though. I post a shot every now and then in a photography subreddit or a small Discord group, but I usually just lurk. I think part of me worries that if I share something and no one reacts, it'll confirm that it wasn't actually that good. Silly, I know, but it sticks.

When I'm not out with my camera, I'm mostly onlineâ€”scrolling through forums, watching videos, sometimes reading. I've got a couple of old friends I message here and there, but I keep it light. Surface-level stuff. I guess I don't really feel up to deeper conversations right now. There's this low-key fear that if I open up too much, people won't really get it or might start seeing me differently.

What kind of stuff do you gravitate toward when you're trying to unwind or reconnect with yourself?

It's telling how activities like cooking that once brought joy can become overwhelming when our energy is low. That transformation of enjoyable things into chores is a particularly difficult experience - especially when part of you remembers how it used to feel different.

I really connect with what you said about photography giving you a sense of control in the midst of chaos. Creative expression can be so important that way. The hesitation to share your work makes a lot of sense too - there's vulnerability in putting your perspective out there, especially when you're not feeling your most confident.

As for me, I find walking outside or listening to music helps me reset. But I'm curious - with everything feeling a bit heavier lately, has it affected your sleep at all? I know for many people those patterns of overthinking can make nights challenging too.

I'm also wondering about those online activities - do you find them satisfying, or are they more of a way to pass time? And has your ability to focus on things like reading changed compared to before these energy fluctuations started?

Yeahâ€¦ that's exactly it. It's not even like I don't want to enjoy those thingsâ€”I remember what it was like to get excited about trying a new recipe or planning a photo walk. But now it feels like there's a wall between the idea and the action. And the more I notice it, the more frustrating it gets. Like I'm letting myself down over and over for not doing "simple" things.

I really like what you said about creative expression being a way to regain control. It kind of is that for me. Like, when I frame a shot and it comes out just right, there's this brief moment of clarity, like "Okay, that's mine. I did that." It doesn't fix everything, but it gives me something real to hold onto, even if I keep it to myself.

Sleepâ€¦ yeah, that's been hit or miss. Some nights I crash out from sheer mental fatigue, but other times I just lie there, replaying conversations or thinking about everything I should be doing. And of course, the later it gets, the more ridiculous the thoughts become. Classic.

Online stuff is mostly justâ€¦ filler, I think. It's not bad, but it doesn't really do anything for me, if that makes sense. Sometimes I scroll just to feel like I'm still plugged in. Reading has definitely been harderâ€”like, I'll start a page and realize halfway through I was thinking about something else entirely. So I reread it, then zone out again. Loop city.

I like the idea of walking or music helping you reset. Do you have a go-to song or album when you're trying to slow down and get out of your head a bit?

That wall between wanting to enjoy something and actually being able to follow through is really tough. The way you described those brief moments of clarity in photography - that feeling of "that's mine, I did that" - is incredibly powerful. It's like a small anchor in the storm. I'm glad you have that, even if it's just occasionally.

For music, I tend to gravitate toward instrumental pieces when I need to reset - sometimes classical, sometimes ambient soundscapes. There's something about music without words that gives my mind space to just be, without adding more thoughts to process.

Those sleep patterns sound exhausting - especially the racing thoughts and conversation replays. When did you first notice these changes in your sleep and concentration? I'm wondering if they appeared around the same time as the difficulty enjoying things, or if one seemed to lead to the other.

I'm also curious - when you look ahead to the coming months, what sorts of things do you find yourself thinking about? And have those thoughts about your future changed compared to, say, a year ago?

Yeah, "anchor in the storm" is a perfect way to put it. I don't get many of those moments, but when I do, they sort of remind me that I'm still here, you know? Still capable of creating something meaningful, even if it feels small or fleeting. It's strange how something so quietâ€”like a good photoâ€”can feel louder than all the noise in my head.

Yeah... the heaviness definitely affects my body, too. It's like everything is slower. Heavier. Like I'm carrying something invisible all the time, and it never lets up.

My brain just wanders off, or goes blank. Even watching a movie is hard sometimes. I'll zone out halfway through and realize I haven't actually been watching it.

It's frustrating, because I feel like I'm losing parts of myselfâ€”my ability to think clearly, to enjoy food, to feel rested. It makes me feel broken. Like my body and mind are both giving up at the same time. And the worst part is, I don't even know how to begin fixing any of it.

Not really, no. My world has gotten so small.

I watch people onlineâ€”smiling in photos, making plans, meeting up for coffeeâ€”and it feels like I'm looking at a world I don't belong to anymore. I want to believe there's still a way back into that kind of life, but... I don't know how. Or if I'm even still someone people would want to be around.
